description: {"blocks":[{"key":"878lt","text":"This protocol was originally folked from \"ARTIC amplicon sequencing protocol for MinION for nCoV-2019\" by Josh Quick to adapt for any illumina sequencers (iSeq, MiSeq, NextSeq, etc.).  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":116,"length":1},{"style":"bold","offset":129,"length":1},{"style":"bold","offset":182,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":42,"length":59}],"data":{}},{"key":"5vru7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"82j23","text":"  Because the PCR products are fragmented and ligated with adapters, this protocol is compatible to many sequencing kits with various read lengths (75PE, 150PE, etc.) for Illumina machines. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"88k59","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d7636","text":"  While the library preparation uses QIAseq FX by Qiagen and is basically straight forward (as par kit instruction but modified to 1/4 scale), some tweaks for much of simplicity and speed were added.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a8lp5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8a73u","text":"Change histories (V2): ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cr3bg","text":"The amount of cDNA input to multiplex PCR is increased (now almost same amount to the ARTIC Network's original protocol) (Step 10). This change gives better results for samples with extremely low RNA copy. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b051h","text":"Amount of adapter solution input was corrected (Step 19).","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"899sm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c5lq2","text":"Change histories (V3): ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9fmr0","text":"RT step has been changed to use of LunaScript (Tyson et al., 2020).","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":47,"length":18}],"data":{}},{"key":"2j5bj","text":"Corrected typos and wrong descriptions about amount of reagents.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7g8bv","text":"Added a link to library quantification protocol.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"h8jn","text":"Other minor changes.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"386a5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6gilp","text":"Change histries (V4):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fg220","text":"Added description about the primer set ver. guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"c8gnd","text":"The important issue you have to consider first is how many samples you will multiplex in single run. This all depends on the capacity of your sequencer and the sample's viral loads represented by Ct-values in qPCR clinical test. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7igss","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"qksf","text":"If a sample contains a relatively high copy number of virus genome (say, Ct \u003c 25),  the obtained reads usually distribute evenly across the genome. In such cases, only 10 Mb (330x) per sample is enough to cover the whole genome with sufficient coverage (\u003e30x). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"66abr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1v7j5","text":"On the other hand, coverage bias increases as a sample's Ct-value increases. Hence, you will need more data to recover relatively weak regions. For samples containing only a low copy number of virus genome (Ct ~ 32), at least 100 Mb (3300x) is desirable to sequence the most part of the genome.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"egkm8","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"e0dr7","text":"Also, if you are going to multiplex many samples in a low-throughput model (e.g. iSeq100), intensive normalization for each sample indix will be needed. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}
